item.title: Gi Nuebun Cho'chu', Gi Nuebun Hinanao
item.description:
H친fa adai todus hamyu! Hu tungu’ na ti m친nggi’ gi halacha gi esti na blog 游땐, laooo gaigi yu’ guini p친’gu! Meeeegagagai na masusedi gi lina’l친’-hu gi ma’pus na mes - gi minag친hit, mampus! 游

Guaha maolek yan b친ba lokkui’ na sinisedi-hu. Fine’nena: i b친ba siha:

  • Makonni’ i neni-hu para 칠spit친t (ya masang친ni yu’ na buenti gai asthma gui’ 游땰)
  • Annai gaigi yu’ giya Gu친han, gumai COVID yu’ (yan todu taotao gi iriy친-hu lokkui’!)
  • 칀ntis di hu dingu i che’cho’-hu, mayulang i komput친-hu 游눹
  • 칀ntis di hu tutuhun i nuebun cho’cho’-hu, mayamak i karet친-hu 游뚳

Gof tristi yu’ gi atyu na tiempu…lao gi minag친hit, gof maolek침a yu’ p친’gu kinu ma’pus na mes. Ya pues p친’gu, i maolek na nutisia:

  • Hu tutuhun macho’chu’ gi Apple 游꼝 (ya ti si침a mandagi yu’…sen maolek i ap친s-hu! Magof yu’ mag친hit put ennao)

Dididi’ na tristi ha’ yu’ sa’ ti mam친han nuebun kareta trabiha, lao hu a’ayao i karet친-침a as sogr친-hu. Puedi mohon na ti apmam bai fam친han, lao hekkua’… 游뱡游낗

LOKKUI’, ti siguru yu’ yanggin esta hu sang친ni hamyu put esti lao kumeke’mama’tinas yu’ guinahan Chamoru NLP! Ti gof bula na bid친-hu p친’gu na si침a hu fa’nu’i hamyu, lao puedi gi mamaila’ na mes!

Todu ha’ para p친’gu. Bula guinaiya! — DJT.

item.title: Trongkun Manggaf친-hu Pt. 2
item.description:
• I Trongkun Manggaf친-hu P친'gu
    • I Bandan Nan친-hu
    • I Bandan Tat친-hu
  • Pues H친fa P친'gu?

First things first: if you haven’t seen my first post re: my family tree then you can read it here.

Okay, nihi ta tutuhun: I’ve been busy, dispensa yu’! I’ve been neck-deep in work and life in general, but I’m here now and I’m excited to share an update on my family tree! 游뗿游낗 I wasn’t sure how much further I’d get honestly - I was doing so much research prior to December that I felt I’d found all the info that I could. Then I subscribed to https://www.chamorroroots.com/v7/, Si침ot Punzalan’s geneaology website, and the excitement came rushing back! I was able to find 21 new people to add to my tree 游땹! And while not as impressive a number, my aunt gave me some documents that gave me 4 more people, and also birth/death years for others who had that data missing 游녪游낗. Needless to say: sen nina’magof yu’ nu esti!

Not much else to say but to give updates.

I Trongkun Manggaf친-hu P친'gu

Note: the colors represent their age at death, and it’s on a sort of gradient. The range is as follows:

  • yellow = 25 years
  • green = 50 years
  • blue = 100 years

The outer white boxes mean I don’t have an age - I either don’t have a birthdate or a deathdate.

I Bandan Nan친-hu

If you compare this photo to the one in my other post, you’ll see I’ve added:

  • Two greatx2 grandparents (on her mom’s side)
  • Four greatx3 grandparents (two on her dad’s side, two on her mom’s)
  • Two greatx4 grandparents (on her mom’s side)

I Bandan Tat친-hu

Compared to the photo of my dad’s side before, I’ve added:

  • Two greatx2 grandparents (on his mom’s side)
  • Eight greatx3 grandparents (four on his dad’s side, four on his mom’s)
  • Six greatx4 grandparents (two on his dad’s side, four on his mom’s)

Pues H친fa P친'gu?

For now I’ll try and start filling out the siblings I guess 游땐? I spent most of my time only focused on the parents, grandparents, etc. Also, knowing that Si침ot Punzalan’s database exist, it’d probably be best to start getting info on folks I know are not in his dataset, e.g., my cousins, my nieces and nephews, etc. Also, I have to start getting more info gi bandan asagu친-hu lokkui’! Gof 친purao yu’ put ennao.

Todu ha’ para p친’gu. Bula guinaiya! — DJT.

item.title: Mama'titinas Diksion친rion Chamoru
item.description:
H친fa adai todus hamyu guennao huyung ni’ tumataitai esti!

It’s been over a month-and-a-half since I’ve blogged and not a week has gone by where I thought to myself, “ai adai, debi di bai fa’tinas otru na blog”, but honestly my schedule has just been todu machalapon. I had to take a step back from dang near everything and reasses my priorities and how I spend my time outside of work - hence my absence 游땐.

BUT it was much needed as I’m here now and ready to share a bit about what I’ve been working on, which is: a personal Chamoru dictionary stored on my computer. This project was born out of three “issues” I kept running into:

  1. My favorite go-to resource for looking up Chamoru words (LearningChamoru.com) required too many steps*
  2. There were a lot of words I couldn’t find when searching
  3. Number 1 seems to only reflect the Guam Orthography, and I wanted something “more complete” (i.e., something with words spelled using the CNMI orthography)

* Too many steps = opening a browser, clicking login, logging in, scrolling down to “Dictionary”, and then searching for a word.

Pues, hu tutuhun i hinanao-hu. I created a template of what I thought a dictionary would look like on the back-end (in a database) and I started gathering as many words as I could find. Anytime I came across a new word, I’d pop open my database and add it in there. It took an egregious amount of time but I finally got to a place where I felt comfortable enough to start working on a “front-end” to access the database. I put that in quotes because in it’s current state I can only access it from a terminal/command-line interface (CLI). I started it off this way sa’ gi minag친het, it’s where I live when I code. Also it’s the fastest way I can access the database. Essentially I created a small program that allows me to access it via the CLI.

Here’s a screenshot of me running the program:

If you’re unfamiliar with what you’re looking at, it’s a terminal/CLI. The points of interest are the second line, where you see 較덕 $ sodda, and then the text afterwards. My program runs when I type sodda and hit enter. I get prompted for a word to search for (in this case I entered " tungo’ “), and then if it finds something I get results back. Otherwise it says it can’t find the word and the prompts just continue until I exit.

Cleaning the data and structuring how everything is stored/returned actually took the most amount of time. I wrote a lot of small helper programs to do things like sort the words, remove misformed words, and add new words, but I still have a lot of work ahead of me. There are still ~3000 words I have that I need to add but don’t have exact translations for. There are also a bunch of words I just straight up don’t have either.

To give you a sense of how big this dictionary has gotten, here is where I’m at:

Currently I store everything in a JSON file, where each word will take up roughly ~20-25 lines. This is near the bottom of the file and as you can see it’s around 340,000 lines (last I checked, there were ~17,000 words). Some functionality is still missing like a) being able to give an English word and get a Chamoru word back, and b) giving suggestions/alternative spellings to what you provided.

Hinasso-ku na sen pairi esti!…lao…there’s one potential problem. I haven’t put this out there yet for everyone to see and try because I actually don’t know if I legally can 游뱂.

I haven’t mentioned this yet, and perhaps you were able to pick it up from earlier when I mentioned why I created this tool, but…I didn’t create a majority of this information from scratch. I made use of LearningChamoru.com, news articles from the GuamPDN, and any blog I could find that seemed like a great resource for filling up a dictionary. So for example, let’s say you use this tool and look up the word “magof” - one of the definitions you’d get back is the same one you’d find in LearningChamoru.com, word-for-word.

Pues hunggan, as much as I want to share this right now, there are still some things I need to figure out. Things like: if I put this dictionary out there, say on a website, would I receive a cease & desist? Could I get sued for copyright infringement? Would I be fine so long as I attribute my data to their correct creators? Etc…

Now that I think about it though…the front-end stuff I can probably share. You’d of course need a dictionary stored in a same-structured JSON, but that general structure I can also share. But for now, this is all I’ll share. When I get more answers and more data and create something more accessible, I’ll give another update!

Todu ha’ para p친’gu. Bula guinaiya! — DJT.

item.title: Mama'titinas Trongkun Mangg친fa
item.description:
I’ve been on a journey to document my family tree in a tech-saavy way. It started off simple: try and find out who my great-grandparents were. I honestly didn’t think I’d get past that because before this I couldn’t even tell you the names of any of my great-grandparents. But as you’ll soon find out, my simple task turned into a research-heavy adventure which is still ongoing.

This wasn’t on my to-do list until recently - I’d say within the last 2 years. I never really thought about any family past my grandparents; I never wondered who their parents or grandparents were. I also gave little thought to who their siblings were. I mean, growing up it just wasn’t something that they talked about. I want to say that I didn’t even know if they had had any siblings, although that became apparent closer to when I was in high school and started meeting extended family. It wouldn’t be until the passing of my grandmas that I would start to pay more attention. And it wouldn’t be until just about 2 years ago that I would start digging into my family history.

| Note: I’ll refer to my grandparents as Grandma/Grandpa A and Grandma/Grandpa T; Aquiningoc and Taitingfong respectively.

Gathering Documents

The first event that really triggered my search was receiving documents about my mom’s side of the family. My aunt had been holding onto them from when she was cleaning house, and I guess she just never thought that it would be of any excitement to us. I recall asking about family names - clan names in particular - and she went to her room to retrieve all the stuff she had. When she came back I was astounded: she had birth certificates, death certificates, legal documents, obituaries, funeral pamphlets, social security cards, and a lot more. The documents that piqued my interest were the ones about my grandma A’s siblings and some homemade lineage documents for my grandpa A’s side. I saw “Aquiningoc” on that paper but none of the names looked remotely familiar.

Later that week I asked my dad what he knew about his parents. He told me not much but that he would ask his siblings what they knew. Within a few hours my dad had text me some scans: a photo of my grandpa T’s mom, a photo of my grandma T and her grandma, and a homemade lineage document detailing my grandma T’s family.

The two lineage documents were incredible finds. The one for my grandma T started with her grandparents. It listed their kids and all the grandchildren. My grandma was one of those grandchildren. Success: I found a set of great-grandparents!

The one for my grandpa A was even more interesting. It was laid out in a similar fashion: grandparents at the top, children below, and grandchildren below that. But my grandpa wasn’t on this list…his dad wasn’t even on the list. I would come to find out that it was my grandpa A’s grandpa listed…as a grandchild! So not only did I find another set of great-grandparents, but a set of their great-grandparents.

I was so amazed yet at the same time a bit sad. These were people I never learned about and, gi minag친het, likely never will. I made a decision right there to document everything I could; to create something that I can pass down to my children and to my siblings and cousins and aunts and todu i manggaf친-hu.

I started writing down names on paper but that got out of hand quickly. Thus started my search for a tool I could easily use and (hopefully) easily share.

Finding the Right Tool

They say the best time to start something was yesterday; the next best time is right now. With that in mind I figured I’d start with a spreadsheet-like program, so I started working in Google Sheets. It started off easy because I had only noted down my immediate family and my grandparents from both sides. When it came to writing down my uncles and aunts though I started to realize that wow: this is going to get out of hand quickly; my dad is 1 of 10, my mom is 1 of 6…I don’t know about my grandparents, but I knew from the documents I had that their families were also “big”.

While continuing to work in Google Sheets I started to also look for alternatives because what started as a 3 sheet file grew into 16 sheets…and that was just going up my family tree, i.e., I was only tracing parents and their parents and their parents and etc. I was able to track i ma침ain친-hu back 6 generations. Things started getting complicated and I needed a new tool.

I temporarily used MyHeritage because it was convenient & had a decent amount of data I could use. There also were people there that had connections to some of my great- and great-great-grandparents, and to be honest that was pretty cool. But MyHeritage had it’s limitations: the desktop app was great, but it felt like most of the magic was happening on the web-side; also, most of the data that I needed to fill in the gaps in my tree were behind paywalls.

Sidebar: I much prefer desktop apps as opposed to web apps. From a business perspective, I understand why web apps are more ubiquitous…but I tend to opt for desktop.

I paused on entering new data and went to search for a different tool. That’s when I came across Gramps, an open-source genealogical research software - it’s essentially a database (DB) with a decent GUI. This felt right up my alley: 1) it’s a desktop app, 2) it’s open-source, and 3) it’s written in my favorite coding language! Okay, I’m getting off track but the point is: I found the right tool.

Once I got the app installed, I probably spent a straight 12 hours just entering information and getting things to a presentable state.

Finding External Sources

I spent a few days on-and-off going between my documents and my DB, but it came to a point where I felt like I’d exhausted all internal sources. I kept trying to climb up my family tree but I eventually hit the canopy, so to speak. I had gained so much momentum and made so much progress that I didn’t want to it stop…but it did. I hit a wall for a few weeks and accepted that I would just continue when something came my way. I stopped working on my tree for about 2 months until I had this urge to revisit my sources, and I’m so glad I did. My next big leaps came in two parts.

Part 1: stumbling upon the incredible work of Si침ot Bernard Punzalan, particularly a PDF he created which contains Chamoru clan names. It was from this PDF that I was able to confirm some clan names that my parents had told me about. I figured, hey: I can probably find more info if I not only searched by my family names but my clan names as well, which ultimately led me to part two.

Part 2: finding a set of great-grandparents for my grandma A via a blog written by P친le’ Eric. It was around this moment that I realized just how much info P친le’ Eric had on his blog. After spending more time reading on his site, I came across another blog which helped me (very likely) confirm my ancestry back 9 generations! Honestly though, I wouldn’t have second-guessed this blog if I hadn’t already spent some time in MyHeritage, because it was there that I discovered more people from my Aquiningoc/Taitano side.

I have a feeling I’ll be able to get more info later on when I’m able to sub to Si침ot Bernard’s Chamorro Roots Database, but for the time being I’ve slowed down on the tree.

My Tree Right Now

As of today, this is what my “family tree” (in fan-form) looks like right now.

My dad’s side:

My mom’s side:

As you can see, I was able to at least get all of my great-grandparents. I’m still missing a few great-great-grandparents, and honestly from there it’s scrambled. Truth be told, I’m incredibly surprised I was able to get as much info as I have! For now I think I’m going to focus on my uncles, aunts, and cousins. I’m hoping to be able to create something that I can share at big family gatherings. I also plan on doing my wife’s side. Gi minag친het, this is fun and relaxing for me.

I think this seals it - I’m our self-proclaimed Family Historian 游땙.

Todu ha’ para p친’gu. Bula guinaiya! — DJT.

Extra info:

  • Gramps GitHub page
  • Other papers by Si침ot Bernard Punzalan

item.title: Ha'친nen "Liberasi칩n"
item.description:
TW/CW: Mentions of war.

I can’t recall a time when my family celebrated “Liberation Day”.

I can recall times that we volunteered at the Sons & Daughters of Guam Club for Liberation fiestas: cleaning, cooking, setting up & breaking down, etc…but being young, I wasn’t interested in the “whys” of fiestas.

But celebrating at home? T친ya’.

I’m positive there’s complexities behind that. I mean, growing up I only ever heard one story about the war from my dad’s mom. It was a quick story, maybe 5 minutes in length, and it ended with her grasping one hand into the other, remembering the pain she felt as a young child from grabbing a freshly-ejected bullet casing that landed fi’on-침a yan i che’lu-침a as they hid gi papa’ trongkon nunu.

As I write now, I’m reminded of how much history my grandparents didn’t pass down. Stories of their childhood, their upbringing, their families, their homes; stories I’ll likely never know. Estoria siha na ni ngai’an hu hunguk’.

But I get it, I really do.

My grandparents were 5-13 years old when this all happened, and it happened damn near in their front yards. The same soil that they walked to church on would become littered with imprints of combat boots in years to come. I try to imagine a boisterous chicken coop or two behind my grandpa’s house, but the imagined memory fades into silence…and then into booms and explosions.

Why would my grandparents want to relive those memories? So I get it, I really do.

And despite all that they had been through, when the time came both my grandpas turned to the U.S. Navy. Maybe they felt they owed it to the U.S. - for the “Liberation” they had received. I have no knowledge of how they came to those decisions, but they made them. And as I sit here in a comfy chair, in an air-conditioned house, where my parents can watch their grandchild respond to me as hu fino’ Chamoruyi gui’…ya si침a ha komprendi yu’?…well, I certainly can’t blame them - at least I don’t want to. They did what they thought was best.

T친ya’ nai na hu silebra esti na ha’친ni. Ya ti hu tungu’ yanggen bai cho’gui’ ennao. What I can and will do is give thanks to i manamko’-ta ni’ manl친’la’ dur친nten i gera. They were forced into an impossible situation and forced to make difficult decisions. Decisions with ramifications still echoing today.

So I’ll end this not with an exclamation of joy, sa’ para gu친hu, ti minagof esti na ha’친ni. Rather, it is a memorial day. A reminder of the courage and tenacity of our people. A reminder that we are still here, fighting for real liberation; for a decolonized status; for independence.

Fanohgi. Fanachu. Fanhassu. Na’l친’la.

Todu ha’ para p친’gu. Bula guinaiya. — DJT.

item.title: Hu Fa'mamaolek Esti na Blog
item.description:
H친fa adai todus hamyu guennao huyung! Hu tungu’ na tumaigui yu’ giya guini, lao hu prometi hamyu na ti 친pmam bai tutuhun m친nggi’ guini. Buenti gumuaha tiempo-ku gi mamaila’ na sem친na, lao siempri gi mamaila’ na mes - puedi ti m친s an친kku’ sa’ malago’ yu’ fa’maolek esti na blog. Bai hu tulaika i “theme” ya hu tungu’ na gumuaha meggai tinilaika siha ni’ hu chek pat chagi.

Todu ha’ para p친’gu. Bula guinaiya! — DJT.

English Translation

Hey everyone out there! I know that I’ve been absent, but I promise y’all that I’ll start writing soon. Maybe I’ll have time in the coming week, but surely I’ll have time in the coming month - hopefully not longer because I want to fix this blog. I’m going to change the theme and I know there’s gonna be plenty to check and test.

That’s all for now. Much love! — DJT.

item.title: Kumeke'etsisiu Yu' Kada Ha'친ni
item.description:
Cha’-hu dagi hamyu. Kumahulo’ yu’ gi taftaf ogga’an kada ha’친ni ya ti malago’ ha’ yu’ umetsisiu. Hu tungu’ na etsisiu u na’labr친bu yu’, lao mapput para hu sodda’ i metgot-hu. LAO mag친het na kumeke’etsisiu yu’ kada ogga’an, pat atu’친si kada ha’친ni…pat kada sem친na, haha.

Esta hu chachagi kum친nnu’ labr친bun n칠ngkanu: meggai gollai, meggai golosina, ya ti hu chagi kum친nnu’ mampus k친tni (lao hu chagi kum친nnu’ n칠ngkanu ginen i tasi kada si침a yu’.) Sen mapput ini na maloffan na s친kkan para todus hit, ya si침a manli’i’ ha’ yu’ tinilaika gi taotao-hu - ya ti maolek ha’! Ti hu duru kekechathinasso put h친fa kinannono-hu, lao esta hu tungu’ na kumak친nnu’ b친ba na n칠ngkanu kada bi친hi si침a na’yamak i taotao-hu. Hu honggi metgot na kinannono-ta u na’tulaika-침a kinu etsisiu-ta.

Lao, gi sinang친n-침iha: kinalamten i kinalamten. Nuebun ha’친ni i agupa'.

Todu ha’ para p친’gu. Bula guinaiya! — DJT.

English Translation

I won’t lie to you. I get up early every day and just don’t want to workout. I know that exercising will make me healthier, but it’s hard to find the strength to do it. BUT I am honestly trying to workout every morning, or at least every day…or every week, haha.

I already try to eat healthier food: lots of veggies, plenty of fruits, and I try not to eat too much meat (but I do try to eat seafood whenever I can). This past year has been really difficult for us all, and I definitely see a change in my body - and it ain’t good! I’m trying not to worry too much about what I eat, but I know that always eating bad food can wreck my body. I strongly believe that our diets cause more change than the exercises we do.

But as they say: progress is progress. Tomorrow is a new day.

That’s all for now. Much love! — DJT.

item.title: Biba Mes Chamoru!
item.description:
H친fa adai todus hamyu guennao huyung! P친’gu na ha’친ni i tinituhun-침a nu Mes Chamoru! Hu tungu’ na ti sessu m친ngge’ yu’ guini, lao hu prometi hamyu na hu chachagi! Kada diha gof tinani’ ha’ yu’: guaha mampus che’cho’-hu, guaha mampus tarehan guma’ put eskuela, ya manh친halom ha’ ham yan i manggaf친-hu gi un nuebun guma'.

Ai adai, fann친’i yu’ i anim친s-miyu fan.

Siempri bai kef친ngge’ guini, kolo’lo’침a sa’ p친’gu i Mes Chamoru. Fanhasso ha’ todus hamyu: sigi ha’ u’usa i fino’-ta; sigi ha’ ume’eyak yan tumutungu’ todu si침a hamyu. Mungnga chumathinasso put linachi gi tinigi’-miyu pat sin친ngan-miyu. Todu maolek ha’. Sigi ha’ chachagi.

Biba Mes Chamoru! Na’l친’la’ todu kosas Chamoru!

Todu ha’ para p친’gu. Bula guinaiya! — DJT.

English Translation

Hello to everyone out there! Today is the beginning of Chamorro Month! I know that I don’t often write write here, but I promise you I’m trying! It’s just every day I’ve been so busy: too much work, too much school homework, and we’re still moving into a new house.

Ai adai, please lend me your strength.

I’ll definitely try to write here, especially because it’s Chamorro Month. Just remember everyone: keep using the language; keep learning all that you can. Don’t worry about errors in your writing or your words. It’s all good. Just keep trying.

Biba Chamorro Month! Celebrate all things Chamorro!

That’s all for now. Much love! — DJT.

item.title: Guaha Mampus Para Cho'gui
item.description:
Ai adai, dispensa na gof atrasao ini na blog! Gi minag친het, sen tinani’ yu’ lao guaha maolek na rason na taiguini. Na’kadada’ un an친kku’ na istoria: ti apmam bai in fa침친ga gi nuebun guma’, yan i ma침ain친-hu yan che’lu-hu. Ohala’ mohon na ti apmam si침a m친nggi’ yu’ kosa ki si침a hu sang친ni hamyu h친fa nuebu gi lina’l친’-hu. Esta otro tiempu nai!

Todu ha’ para p친’gu. Bula guinaiya! — DJT.

English Translation

My goodness, apologies for this late blog! Truthfully, I’m super busy but there’s a good reason for that. Long story short: I’m moving soon into a new house, along with my parents and sister. Hopefully I can write soon so I can give an update on life. Until next time!

That’s all for now. Much love! — DJT.

item.title: I Lahi-hu Kumpreprendi i Ilelek-hu
item.description:
Kada diha hu usa fino’ Chamoru gi i gima’-hu yan i famili친-ku, i asagu친-hu yan i lahi-hu, si Lorie yan si Leo. Gi minag친het, ti sessu hu usa nuebu na pal친bra siha yan siha, lao siempri hu adingani siha gi fino’ Chamoru. Guaha na bi친hi na hu ke’usa nuebu na pal친bra siha, pi칩t yan i lahi-hu, ya kada diha si침a manli’i’ yu’ na ha na’la’tungu’ gui’. Hu tungu’ na ha kumprendi annai hu sang친ni gui':

  1. Maila’ m친gi
  2. Nihi ta tulaika (i mag친gu-mu / i pa침친les-mu)
  3. Huchum i petta fan
  4. Mungnga (mamacha, pumacha, kumassas, tum친ngis, etc.)
  5. Chiku fan
  6. Kao 침친lang hao?

Banidosu yu’ nu guiya, ya gi minag친het banidosu yu’ lokkui’ nu guahu na si침a hu adingani yan i famili친-ku gi fino’ Chamoru, achokka’ adumididi'.

Todu ha’ para p친’gu. Bula guinaiya! — DJT.

English Translation

Everyday I use Chamoru in my house with my family, my wife and my son, Lorie and Leo. Honestly, I don’t often use new words with them, but I certainly talk to them in Chamoru. Sometimes I try to use new words, especially with my son, and I can see that everyday he learns a bit more. I know that he can understand when I say:

  1. Come here
  2. Lets change (your clothes / your diaper)
  3. Close the door please
  4. Don’t (touch anything, touch that, scratch, cry, etc.)
  5. Kiss please
  6. Are you hungry?

I’m proud of him, and honestly I’m proud of myself too that I can converse with my family in Chamoru, even if just a little.

That’s it for now. Much love! — DJT

item.title: Minalago' Siha Para I Tinilaikan I Sakkan
item.description:
H친fa adai todus hamyu! Guaha un nuebun s친kkan ya malago’ yu’ pum친tti hamyu ni hinasso-ku siha para iyo-ku blog para i mamaila’ s친kkan.

Guaha ideha-hu siha na hinasso-ku siempri na’d친ngkulu i tiningu’-hu gi Fino’ Chamoru, ya eyu nai bai m친nggi’ put:

  1. Manggaf친-hu
  2. Nengk친nu’ ni’ chumocho yan mama’tinas yu'
  3. Lepblo-ku siha ni’ manaitai yu'
  4. Todu kosas gi Tek

Esta m친nggi’ yu’ ni manggaf친-hu lao ya-hu bai m친nggi’ nu nengk친nu’, lepblo siha, yan tek, kulolo’침a put sigurid치t gi tek. Ti hu cho’gui sigurid치t gi che’cho’-hu, lao eyu kada diha hu na’saonao gi lina’l친-hu - ti manli’i’ yu’ lokkui’ tinigi’ siha put eyu gi Fino’ Chamoru. Gai lepblu siha na Chamoru yu’ p친’gu ni’ i asagu친-hu yan i ki침친du-hu ma n친’i yu’ para Krismas, ya gi minag친het ti si침a mannangga yu’ manaitai siha. Hu fakchacha’i i mamaila’ s친kkan yan tutuhun tumugi’ iyo-ku blog siha put ideha-hu siha. Ya ta’lu, na’tungu’ yu’ yanggen gai linachi gi iyo-ku blog pat guaha sinang친n-mu.

Esta, todu ha’ para p친’gu. Yanggen ni h친yiyi na sang친ni hao trabiha, Biba Tinilaikan i Sakkan!

Bula guinaiya — DJT.

English Translation

Hello everyone! It’s a new year and I wanted to share with you my thoughts for my blog for the coming year.

I have a few ideas that I think will help expand my Chamoru, and that’s to write about:

  1. My family
  2. Food I’ve eaten & made
  3. Books I’ve read
  4. All things in Tech

I’ve already written about my family but I’d like to write about food, books, and tech, especially security in tech. Security isn’t what I do at work, but it is something I incorporate into my daily habits - also it’s not something I’ve seen written about in Chamoru. I got some Chamoru books for Christmas from my wife and her brother, and honestly I can’t wait to read them! I’m looking forward to the coming year and to start writing about these topics. And again, let me know if there’s any mistakes or comments you have.

Well, that’s it for now. If nobody has told you yet, Happy New Year!

Much love — DJT.

item.title: Magof P친sgua Nochebuena 2020
item.description:
H친fa adai todus hamyu yan Magof P친sgua Nochebuena para siha ni’ ma침ilebra.

Christmas time for me today has shifted mostly towards i bandan asagu친-hu. Gi minag친het, hagas ha’ hu silebra Nochebuena yan i famili친-침a. On my side of the family we tend to split time between my dad’s side and my mom’s side. Even then, those parties tend to be closer to New Years or after, i.e., my family tends to celebrate Christmas after New Years — ya maolek-침a i “sales” dispues di New Years ki antes, hunggan? 游땐

Guaha bula hinasso-ku siha ginen tiempon Krismas yan i famili친-ku. It was definitely one of the happiest times of the year for me: bula nengk친nnu’, gaigi todu mamprim친-hu gi gima’, ya mang친nta yan manmanayuyut ham. Mah친lang yu’ nu eyu tiempu.

I miss it - more so lately.

During Kasiyas 20201, guaha taotao ni’ k친nta i kantan P친sgua Nochebuena. Muna’hasso yu’ nu i famili친-ku. It had been so long since I’ve heard those songs - about a decade or so as of this writing. Growing up, it was a common sound…but after my dad’s mom passed, things changed. She was the one who always hosted I Nobenan Ni침o2. Si침a hu hunguk eyu na k친nta siha trabiha…: Fanm친tto Manhengge, Kant친yi Gui’, O Patgon Belen, etc… Hearing them sing those songs inundated me with memories and I found myself wishing I had spent more time cherishing those moments; wishing I had pictures or footage; wishing my grandma was still alive and we could do i Nobenan Ni침o just one more time.

Hu tungu’ na si침a hu bisita otro taotao ni’ ma침ilebra i Nobenan Ni침o, lao ti parehu eyu yanggen taigui i famili친-ku. Ohala na gumaigi yu’ yan i ma침ain친-hu lamo’na. Mah친lang yu’ nu siha.

Todu ha’ para p친’gu.

Bula guinaiya — DJT.

  1. Tinigi’-hu put Kasiyas 2020 ↩︎

  2. Guampedia article on Nobenan Ni침o ↩︎

item.title: Kasiyas 2020
item.description:
Hu tugi’ ini na poem para Kasiyas 2020; put hu sohyu’ todus hamyu para konsigi fumino’ Chamoru. Yanggen malago’ hao umegga’, si침a hao gi Facebook –> click here (manaitai yu’ gi ~45 minutes 游녨游낖) — translation below poem

Fino’ Chamoru

Mungnga ma똮봭똮쎠o fumino Chamoru, Achokka ennao muna뗤a똮봭똮쎠o hao. Achokka hinasso-mu na mapput para h친gu, Maolek침a kumekefino’ ki pum친para

Si침a un tutuhun p친뗞u na ha똮볉i, Lao maolek ha yanggen ti si침a hao. Si침a un tutuhun hao agupa lokkui, Hasso nai, ni ngai’an gof atrasao.

Achokka’ gof chaochao i hinanao-mu Pat ann친kku lokkui, taiguennao para guahu. Lao, mungnga nai chumathinassu, Yanggen malago’ hao ayuda, pues gaigi yu.

Ya mangaigi siha lokkui, todu manga’chong-ta; Todu taotao guennao huyung ni mane뗜yak. Todu i taotao muna뗣친뗣a뗣a’ i fino-ta, Manmalago ham manmanayuda todus gi hinanao-ta.

Pues na똮볂ang i bos-mu annai ume’eyak hao, Achokka na tristi pat gof yayas hao, Sa anngen un usa i fino Chamoru, H친gu muna’l친’la’la’ i kuttur친-mu

Sa hahasso nai뵻anggen ti hita, pues h친yi?

I wrote this poem for Kasiyas 2020; I wrote it to persuade people to continue learning to speak Chamoru. If you want to watch, you can on Facebook –> click here (I read at ~45 minutes 游녨游낖).

I’d prefer not to translate the poem, at least not right now…I feel it takes away from the overall meaning of the poem. If you’d like a translation, get in touch! We can work through it together.

item.title: Adingani i Lahi-hu Pt. 2
item.description:
I finene’na na blog guini.

Buenas yan h친fa adai todus hamyu! 칀pmam na tiempu na m친nggi’ yu’ guini, hunggan? Gi minag친het, gof tinani’ yu’ desde ki t친tti hugua na pulan. Kada diha hu ripiti ta’lu na bid친-hu: makm친ta yu’ yan etsisiu pat chochu, pues macho’chu’, ya pues hug친ndu yan i lahi-hu. Todu eyu ha tifi’ yu’, lol.

I asunto put ini na blog kosa ki hu m친s p친tti hamyu ni taiminapput sin친ngan siha na hu sang친ni i lahi-hu.

Yanngen gailinachi gi ini na tinigi’-hu, pues sang친ni yu’ fan — Estudi친nti ha’ yu’ yan kada diha tumutungu’ yu'.

Sin친ngan Siha Ni’ Hu Sang친ni i Lahi-hu

Chamoru English
Para m친nu hao? Where are you going?
H친fa un li’i’ gi hiyung? What do you see outside?
Kao un li’i’ i batkun airi? Did you see the airplane?
Mungnga mamacha ni iyo-ku Don’t touch my stuff
Kao h친spuk pat 침친lang ha’ hao? Are you full or still hungry?
H친fa iyo-mu? Gi kannai-mu? What do you have? In your hand?
Hu tungu’ na yayas hao pues maigu’ p친’gu I know you’re tired so sleep now
Ai adai, kao tum친ki’ hao? Gof mutung! Ai adai, did you poop? So stinky!
Nihi ta tulaika i pa침친les-mu Let’s change your diaper
Gimen i gimen-mu leche kosa ki para ta fanmaigu' Drink your milk so we (3) can go to sleep

Todu ha’ para p친’gu.

Bula guinaiya. DJT.

English Translation

The 1st blog is here.

Hello everyone! It’s been a long time since I’ve written here, yeah? Honestly, I’ve been really busy these past two months. Every day, I do what I typically do: wake up and exercise or eat, then I work, and then I play with my son. It all drains me, lol.

The reason for this blog is so that I can share more simple phrases I tell my son.

If there are mistakes in this blog, then tell me please — I’m still a student and learning every day.

Phrases I Tell My Son

拘 go back up to read the phrases 游때

That’s it for now.

All love. DJT.

item.title: Mampus Chaddek i Lahi-hu
item.description:
Kada diha, hu li’i’ mal친lagu i lahi-hu gi uriyan guma’-m친mi. Gaigi gui’ gi me’nan potta, pues ha mal친gu h친lum i kuatton-m친mi, pues gaigi gui’ gi tatti yu’ pat fi’on-hu. Ai adai, guaha na bi친hi ti si침a hu sodda’ i tiempu para dumesk친nsa.

Lao gi minag친het, eyu ha na’magof yu’ sa’ hu lili’i’ gui’ dum친ngkulu; m친s chumach친lek gui’, gof ya-침a humug친gandu yan hami yan si Lorie asagu친-hu, ya bula kumukuentus gui'!

Ti si침a hu nangga para lumi’i’ h친fa guaha na umeyak gui'.

Todu ha’ para p친’gu // Bula guinaiya — DJT.

English Translation

Every day, I see my son running around our house. He’s at the front door, then he runs into the room, then he’s behind me or right next to me. My goodness, sometimes I can’t find the time to relax.

But honestly, it makes me happy because I’m seeing him grow; he’s laughing more, he really likes playing with me and my wife, and he’s talking so much!

I can’t wait to see what else he learns.

That’s it for now // Much love — DJT

item.title: Adingani i Lahi-hu
item.description:
Note: updated 2020-12-22 by removing reference to my since-deleted write.as blog.

Most of the Chamoru that I’ve been using lately is towards i lahi-hu. H친cha na s친kkan id친t-침a, pues inadingan-m친mi ni ti mapput.

I wanted to share some of those phrases with you and perhaps get some feedback. If you’re here then I’ll assume you came from Twitter, IG, or some other social media site. Feel free to hit me up on any of those.

Nihi ta tutuhun.

Sin친ngan Siha ni’ Hu Sang친ni i Lahi-hu

Phrases I Tell My Son

Chamoru English
Nihi ta tulaika i mag친gu-mu Let’s change your clothes
Nihi ta h친nao Let’s go
H친nao! Huyung neni Go! Out neni
H친nao yan sodda’ si nan친-mu Go and find your mom
H친fa bidad친-mu? What are you doing?
N친’i yu’ nu gi kannai-mu Give me what’s in your hand
Kao 침친lang hao? Are you hungry?
Kao malagu’ hao chumochu? Do you want to eat?
Kao h친spuk hao? Are you full?
Kao ma’o hao? Are you thirsty?
H친yi ennao/eyu? Who is that?
Maila’ m친gi Come here
Nihi ta baila! Let’s dance!
Baila’ yan guahu Dance with me
Mungnga mangassas hao fan Don’t scratch yourself please
Mungnga ennao Don’t do that
Mungnga kum친ti fan Please don’t cry
Sa’ h친fa kum친kati hao neni? Why are you crying neni?
Atan yu' Look at me
Kao matuhuk hao? Are you sleepy?
Kao esta yayas hao? Are you already tired?

Definitely simple phrases that I hope my son will catch on to. Gi minag친het, hu tungu’ na ha kumprendi na ilek-hu ya ennao ha gof na’magof yu’.

Todu ha’ para p친’gu.

Bula guinaiya — DJT.

item.title: I Tinituhon
item.description:
Note: Updated 2020-12-22 with added English title.

Buenas yan h친fa adai todus hamyu! Guahu i che’lun-miyu as David Taitingfong ya ini iyo-ku na blog ni’ un taitaitai.

I’ve been meaning to get this space started for some time but, if I’m being honest, so many things have gotten in my way - and by many things I mean myself and the plethora of projects that I can’t seem to stop accruing. But as they say: there’s no better time than the present…so here we are!

This blog will largely represent my journey in learning the Chamoru language. I’m going to try and utilize tags and categories as much as possible to keep things organized, but you can expect to see writings of all forms: lessons, poems, sporadic thoughts, etc.

Bear in mind that I still consider myself a beginner in this space (particularly when it comes to conversing) so if you read something and think, “Ai adai, milachi gi tinigi’-mu”, then cut me some slack pot fabot. Ya hunggan, si침a ha’ para un li’i’ bula na ini, i.e., I’ll be switching from English to Chamoru and vice versa. My goal is to use as much Chamoru as possible but ai adai, guaha na bi친hi na si침a makkat ennao, lao bai hu chagi.

Hopefully you find my writings interesting. Hopefully this journey never ends and we find our paths crossing at some point. Todu ha’ para p친’gu. Fanadahi todus hamyu.

Bula guinaiya - DJT.
